resources.string: The Burj Khalifa, is a skyscraper in Dubai, U.A.E. With a total height of 829.8 m, the Burj Khalifa is currently the tallest structure in the world.
The Burj al-Arab is a 7 star luxury hotel located in Dubai, U.A.E. It is the third tallest hotel in the world.
Atlantis, The Palm is a UAE luxury hotel resort located at the apex of the Palm Jumeirah in the United Arab Emirates.
The Wild Wadi Water Park is an outdoor water park in Dubai, U.A.E. Situated in the area of Jumeirah, next to the Burj Al Arab.
Coya: Coya not only serves the best food in the city, but some of the best dishes we\'ve eaten anywhere. Ever. It\'s popular and has been since it opened.
Play: A restaurant that opened with an air of exclusivity, this new "Mediterrasian" eatery takes the two cuisines and puts together dishes to stunning effect.
Pai Thai: Yes, it has been around a while, and yes, it\'s popular with tourists. But it\'s also absolutely fantastic.
Nusr-Et: Serving Turkish classics and some of the best cuts of meats in town, Nusr-Et has done wonders since it opened, managing to combine fine dining with a no-nonsense approach.
Mall of the Emirates: MOE is the ultimate destination for leisure, entertainment, and shopping. It is also the world’s first shopping resort with dual five star hotels.

Ibn Battuta: Ibn Battuta was a 14th Century Arab scholar who travelled 120,000 km over 30 years. This mall, inspired by him, gives us an insight into the places he has visited. Who wouldn\’t love a bit of medieval scenery while shopping?
Deira City Centre: It may not be the shiniest and it is definitely not the biggest, but Deira City Centre has always been one of the favourite shopping destinations for the residents of old Dubai.

Dubai Mall: Now it\'s time for the most elaborate mall of them all, although the one with the least elaborate name: The Dubai Mall. It\’s the largest in the world and there is barely a brand or outlet that isn\’t set up here.

Ras Al Khor Wildlife Sanctuary: This large salt water lagoon is only 10 minutes drive from World Trade Centre and you can see large numbers of migratory wild birds including flamingoes and eagles from the hides.

MAKE Business Hub: An urban cafe that promotes entrepreneurs and aims to foster creativity with free-to-use facilities, workshops and seminars. A good place to go if you are in Dubai for business or want to network.
Bastakiya: The Emirati breakfasts and lunches at the Cultural Centre in Bastakiya go down well with my guests. The food is cooked and served by locals who will chat to you about life in UAE.
Pavilion Downtown: They have art exhibitions, a library, cafe and cinema showing local and international films.
